subject: Re: [junit] assertEquals(array1, array2)
msgSnippet: ... One of the reasons we put some effort into the expectation classes is that we ve found that good error reporting is more important than one might think and
messageBody:
> If you want Set like behaviour i.e. not containing duplicate entries this
> can be done more simply
> (but with less diagnostics) like this:
>
> assertEquals( new HashSet( Arrays.asList( expectedArray ) ), new
> ashSet( Arrays.asList( actualArray ) ) );
>
> assuming the object in the array has a working hashCode.

One of the reasons we put some effort into the expectation classes is that we've found that good error reporting is more important than one might think and really helps you find the fault quickly.

The trouble with comparing arrays after the fact is that it's too late and sometimes it can take forever to work through the relevant code to find the problem. I suspect that error management in unit tests is like refactoring, you can get away with things in the short term but it really pays to be anal about it...

Steve
